instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
This board came in with only slight corrosion on <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and no backlight. I replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and got backlight back, but not completely. On the left half of the screen only half of the leds are on, resulting in a row of dark spots. I tried different screens first, but they show the same pattern.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_6</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]5,4V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_5</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]5,4V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_4</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0,5V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0,5V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_2</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0,5V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_1</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0,58[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0,5V[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]


I assumed my soldering might be bad and replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> with a new one. No change.

<SIGNAL>P5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are stable. I checked <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_1</SIGNAL>; it has connectivity to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

LVDS connector looks pristine, inside as well as outside. Pins are all properly fixed in place. 

Are these <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN</SIGNAL> voltages normal? Whats next? replace <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> again with lower heat to make sure its not messed up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
Diode mode readings are good, not bad solderings; no need to change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.
But you should check if all resistors have 0 ohm, as you have bad voltage on two lines.
You could have bad connections inside J8300.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
Resistors are all measuring as 0-2 Ohms, connections from resistors to J8300 are fine.
I've replaced J8300; still have the same problem.
You mentioned I have bad voltage on two lines; which ones? I dont know what normal readings are for these rails and have no comparison (except older pro's which seem to be different).

I measured all <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN</SIGNAL> lines after working on the board; they're the same as before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
You get 5.4V on return 5/6 lines.

Reflow <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, or tru other chip.

Did you try full LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
update: I measured continuity from all 6 <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN</SIGNAL> resistors to the corresponding balls on <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. Had to fix the board upright and use a very small probe point, but I got what I wanted to know. 

Backlight stopped working. I replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> (again) and it worked, but again with the same dark spots on the left half of the screen. Just now, backlight died again.
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> is 8.4V now.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are fine.

I measured all resistors surrounding <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> - all are fine. Pads underneath <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> looked fine as well... 

I've been testing with three different full lcd assemblies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message: I have now; area just above <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and the test point above it are perfectly clean, no corrosion. measuring 0 Ohms from test point to <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and also from test point to pad 5 from <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
I fixed the board by taking a <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> from a donor board and using that. 
I can think of two reasons for my previous replacements not working;
1. bad soldering
2. bad IC's.

I think my soldering was fine; checked all sides under the microscope and could see no dodgy stuff. Also, my three replacement chips all failed in the same way. I'm now doubting whether my <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>'s are dodgy. Here's a side by side pic of the two. Left is the original corroded IC, right is the replacement.

[ATTACH]59306[/ATTACH]

Has anyone had trouble with these IC's before? I got these from alibaba.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message:
I never had problems with <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> chips.
I only bought them from Aliexpress last 3 years...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message: Weird.. I guess I did mess up the soldering then, nothing else I can think of.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message: I had to do the same thing on a board I worked on over a year ago. I replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> due to no backlight and had some leds not working. I thought "it couldn't have been my soldering" but sure enough, I pulled the board out of my rabbit hole box a year later, replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and all the backlight LEDS came on. It is crazy the things we can miss when we are in a rush.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - backlight working partially
threads.message: Thankfully the BL circuit is small, so pretty easy to figure it out.
